description.text: This was a simple earring set I made on commission. I thought it turned out pretty well.  They might even turn out better if there were more than one pair printed at a time such that the plastic had more time to cool between layers.  But the trihedral bonding looks pretty visually interesting.

• Print these with exterior support vertically. Unless you increase the size of these, you have to print the honeycomb vertically to get it to print that thin. I tried it horizontally but the tool path always left gaps in the honeycomb.

  • Carefully remove the support and clean the edges with a knife or Dremel tool.

  • Install an earring hook on each one.

  • Install a plastic retainer tube on the back of each hook to prevent them from being lost when worn.

title: Interior webcam mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Interior webcam mount for a Makerbot Replicator 2 and its clones. This bracket is designed for a Logitech C270. The camera mount allows for the camera to be put on horizontally and vertically.

Any tips/tricks on how to use or improve the design, feel free to post a comment! Feed back is greatly appreciated.

Printer:

Qidi Tech

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Fixed height installation instructions
  1. Assemble the wall_mount.stl part by inserting M4 nuts into the slots.
  2. In the desired corner, replace the pair of middle exterior screws with M4 x 12mm screws. Do not screw them in all the way, only until they ends are flush with the threaded holes on the inside.
  3. Slide the wall_mount.stl part over the threaded indents on the inside corner.
  4. Finish threading in the screws from Step 2. The mount should be tightly held in the corner.
  5. Screw in the camera_mount.stl in whatever orientation you want with a M4 x 12mm screw.
  6. Screw in the Logitech C270 into the camera_mount.stl part with a M3 x 16mm screw. Tighten it such that the camera is snug and won't rotate anymore.
Variable height installation instructions
  1. Complete steps 1-4 from Fixed height installation instructions.
  2. Complete steps 1-4 from Fixed height installation instructions, but this time on the mount point above the one you installed previously.
  3. Bridge the 2 wall_mount.stl parts with the height_adjustment.stl and secure it with M4 x 12mm screws at the top and bottom.
  4. While holding the nut_backing.stl still, thread the final M4 x 12 mm screw through the camera_mount.stl and height_adjustment.stl into the nut_backing.stl. The camera_mount.stl can be in whatever orientation you want.
  5. Screw in the Logitech C270 into the camera_mount.stl part with a M3 x 16mm screw. Tighten it such that the camera is snug and won't rotate anymore.

Printed Parts
  • 2x wall_mount.stl
  • 1x height_adjustment.stl
  • 1x nut_backing.stl
  • 1x camera_mount.stl
Additional Hardware
  • 7x M4 x 12mm button head screws
  • 7x M4 nuts
  • 1x M3 x 16mm screw
  • 1x M3 nut

Printed Parts
  • 1x wall_mount.stl
  • 1x camera_mount.stl
Additional Hardware
  • 3x M4 x 12mm button head screws
  • 3x M4 nuts
  • 1x M3 x 16mm screw
  • 1x M3 nut

How to remove original mount from the camera

I have no idea.....

I ended up using a hacksaw and cutting it off, making sure not to cut any of parts attached to the camera itself. I ended up breaking the original pin and I had some M3 screws laying around....

Look in the comments to see if anyone posts a better solution.

Cable Management

If you are looking for some better cable management with the webcams USB cable, then run the cable before installing the wall_mount.stl part(s).

title: Fenrad® TW64 4.0 Smart Watch Charging Unit Replacement Clip

description.text: My son broke the clip on his Fenrad® TW64 4.0 Bluetooth Smart Bracelet Wrist Watch charging unit so I made a new one. The watch itself only cost £16 but rather than replace the whole thing, I drew it from scratch. I used an infill of 100% for strength and found another spring of a similar size to the original as the old one pinged off somewhere. I used the foam insert from the original part, which I very carefully removed to prevent damage. If you have one of these that's broken, then this will save you a few quid and your time.

author: NikDak

description.text: If you're like me, you probably disassemble your extruder slightly more often than you would prefer to. I got tired of keeping track of that little 2.5mm hex key and designed some thumb knobs that would be small enough to maintain my OEM look and function, but have enough grip to securely torque together the extruder assembly.

After a few tries, I found that printing at .2mm layer height and increasing the scale by 6% with 2 shells at 50% infill produced satisfactory results. I ran my HBP at 60C with no filament fan which is the cause for the very poor looking prints.   
Once these were done printing, I used a #12 scalpel blade to shave off the tiniest bit of plastic to get the perfect fit i wanted and secured each piece to the head of the bolt using a drop of CA glue. Make sure the bolts aren't in your machine while the CA is being applied. capillary action will pull the glue deep inside your extruder assembly. but on the bright side, if this does happen, you'll never have to take your extruder apart again. Cheers!

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the Ooznest Prusa i3 hot end fan shroud included in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:659585 , and it fits in with the original nuts and bolts. The new part has places for two 25mm fans. One of them is pointed at the hot end, like in the original. The other fan points towards the extruder barrel, in order to avoid "heat creep" when printing with PLA. I was unable to do long duration PLA prints with my Ooznest Prusa i3 with the original fan shroud, as the filament would get stuck in the extruder. Adding extra cooling in addition to disabling retraction solved the problem.

EDIT: Well, it didn't. I got one successful print with this mod, but after that the heat creep was back. Back to the drawing board.

We needed a good labeling solution for our library's graphic novel collection.  At any given time, 50% of the collection is checked out - often entire series.  This means a standard labeling solution would result in dead space on the shelves.  Our solution was a basic label design that could be printed quickly.  With this design, we snap a 3/4 inch disc magnet to the back, attatch our old clear vinyl card pockets to the front, and slip in a label featuring the series title.  With labels made for every series, our shelvers can tailor this modular labeling system to whatever series are currently checked-in, creating an engaging and browsing friendly display.  
Nothing fancy, but I thought some other librarian or organizationally obsessed maker might benefit from the design.

Print object
Snap in 3/4 inch disc magnet (you may want to add glue, depending on magent strength)
Attach clear pocket (optional)
Slip in or attach printed label
Support material

title: Key for road booms common in Sweden

description.text:
This is the first thing ive designed in 3d, ive tested it and it works just fine.

To start off, i dont know if these kinds of locks are used anywhere else but Sweden, here ive seen them in many places.

The key works on swinging booms, lifting booms and some booms with padlocks.

I made this by using calipers on the original item, looking at guides youtube and after trying the first version i made some modifications based on feeling and function.

This is iteration two, while the first could open these locks but it didnt open the one pictured since it has an anti tamper cowling around the key hole and i had made the key to short to turn the "handle" inside the cowling, the ring on the back was hitting it.

The changes i did were to lengthen the key a bit, made the ring on the end a little smaller, thickened the tooth that pushes the lock around and made the indentation on the front end shallower for strenght, it didnt need to be as deep as on the original key.

M3D Micro

title: Key Topper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I like the little plastic protectors for keys that you can get, but you usually have to get a key with it on there when you get it cut. And no they aren't expensive, but here are my reasons for creating this.

  1. I am an Über Maker, so I needed a key topper that sets me apart.
  2. I wanted a simple but stylish way to identify my house key.
  3. This is a baby step towards possibly making a customizer for this, so that people could include logo's or names or some form of identifier right on the key topper.

I got pretty good results from our Printrbots in the Shop (TechShop Chandler). But the new Zortrax (with whom I'm currently having an affair!) printer should produce phenomenal results.

My design files are available on TinkerCad (where I designed them). So please Tinker away and modify them!

Printer:

Zortrax

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Very High

Infill:

100%

I wish I was good enough to engineer little snap fittings into the two pieces so that they snap together. But I really don't think they would hold. So my plan is to just super-glue the two pieces together on the key.

Designed on Inkscape and TinkerCad! The project is open to the public so feel free to grab the project and Tinker away with it.

Basically I created an outline of the key. So I scanned the key in on a scanner, imported that into Inkscape. Manually traced the head shape. Then sized it to match the physical key. Then I etched the shape out of wood on a laser cutter to make sure the size matched the key. Then I went back into Inkscape to create the shapes for the walls and hole. Next I imported those shapes into Tinkercad and extruded them. Then it was off to the 3d printer for the first run.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1aGQ2oCnL0C

For the sake of auto bed levelling, I downloaded the latest available 1.1.0 RC7 Marlin firmware from official github which was released on 31 July 2016 and configured it for my Sunhokey Prusa i3 2015 which has an MKS Gen v1.1 board. I think X and Y steps would be ok for most people but your Z and E-steps may vary.

It is working great so far and there is clear difference in motion, not sure if it's due to firmware or configuration but it's surely not a placebo. I printed a nut/bolt thing @ 0.1 resolution and it came out just fine but any tweaks / suggestions are welcomed since i'm not a firmware expert.

P.S. Auto bed levelling option is not enabled by default so you can enable and configure it as needed. Latest Arduino software is recommended for flashing. There are plenty of resources available on internet about how to flash marlin firmware.

title: E3D Titan2 Dual titan extruder mount

description.text: This is a mount for two titans. In my setup I made it for a flying effector design on a delta printer. If you can print in Colorfabb XT-CF that is ideal. The high temperature resistance of the XT is valuable but the Stiffness keeps the springs from deforming the Base. Go forth and build beautiful things!

Printer:

Kolossal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

100% fill for very stiff parts in XT-CF. I wanted very clean beautiful parts so I took a little extra time and printed at .1 layer height. Feel free to make whatever you desire.

Assembly

Pull the bearings out of the two titans you will have purchased or source just the right bearings. You'll need to shave off one side of the filament support tube so that it fits as well. You'll see what I mean. If you're putting this on a delta then glue the flying extruder to the back of the titan2 base.

comments.text:
Merlincode, If you mean the black which attaches to the white center barbs, that's surgical tubing. It's meant to suspend the extruder between the carriages on a delta machine.
Flyer007, The fan helps keep the filament cold so that the teeth don't make as deep of impressions. If you're only extruding .1mm of filament but the diameter is misshapen you will get ripples in the width of filament extruded in your part. Doesn't help with surface finish.
Odys, This has worked very well since last October. I've never had to change anything out thus far.

author: juanpis

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dB2COVmkPGl

print_settings.Notes:: PLA Filament

description.text:
Being a Star Wars action figures collector, one of my first interests was always making good stands for showing my collection adequately. As it was growing bigger & bigger, space requirements were getting critical. One of my first solutions was to make a grandstand using glass strips (thickness: 2mm, 400 mm long, 50 mm wide) supported by polystyrene columns fixed to the former ones, all over a glass shelf, not shown in these pictures. What I intend to do with this THING is to replace the polystyrene columns with PLA columns now fixed not to the strips, but to the glass shelfs, improving cleanning up activities.
For a working set of supports, you must print: 2 (two) single platforms [Encastre], 8 (eight) bases [Base], 6 (six) separators [Separador], 4 (four of each type of columns), 8 (eight) column capitals [Capitel] and 16 (sixteen) fences [Tope].
If you choose to print only 2 (two) fusion platfoms [Fusion], you don´t have to print any single platform [Encastre], base [Base] or separator [Separator]

Printer:

PrintRite Colido 2.0 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,15 mm

Infill:

20 %

Notes:

PLA Filament

1.- Attaching 8 (four) "Bases" to 2 (two) "Encastres".

In order to attach the bases of the columns [Base Columna.stl] to the single platforms [Encastre Bases.stl], some glue is strongly required. If you have chosen to print the fusion platform variant [Fusion], avoid this step.

2.- Attaching 6 (six) "Separadores" to 2 (two) "Encastres".

Attaching the base separators [Separador Base.stl] to the platforms [Encastre Bases.stl]. Glue is again strongly required. If you have chosen to print the fusion platform variant [Fusion], avoid this step.

3.- Attaching 4 (four) of each type of "Columnas" to 8 (eight) "Bases".

It is time to attach the columns [Columna ##.stl] to bases [Base Columna.stl]. Glue is not necesary. If you have chosen to print the fusion platform variant [Fusion], this is your first step.

4.- Attaching 16 (sixteen) "Topes" to 8 (eight) "Capiteles".

Attaching the step fences [Tope Escalon.stl] to the column capitals [Capitel Columna.stl]. Glue is mandatory. For most cases it was required a scissor blade to enlarge the holes of the capitals for the step fences. To avoid this problem I modified steps dimensions for improving tolerances, but only next print would prove them to be right or wrong.

5.- Finishing

In order to finish the pair of supports, the next step is to mount column capitals with fences on tops of the columns. Glue is not required. The set is ready to be fixed to a glass shell using double-sides ribbons, for example.

Design Parameters

It was designed using Autodesk AutoCAD 2010 software.
The dimensions of the platforms (the bottom pieces of the set, where all the others attatch to), take into account a desired separation of 50 mm for the columns, and also tolerances por mounting side by side bases and separators. They consider an extension at the back for aligning properly against the glass shelf edge, in order to facilitate sticking, pasting or taping.
Top fences which are added to the column capitals in order to grab the glass strips (steps of the grandstand), are made for 50 mm wide strips.
Platforms [Encastre Bases.stl], separators [Separator] and fences [Tope Escalon.stl] are the only pieces that would require changing for other glass strip dimensions. If required, it would be grate for me to satisfy (upload) any request.
Single platforms [Encastre], bases [Base] and separator [Separator] are fused in a new variant of plataform [Fusion], being this one a recommended option for simplifying printing and assembling jobs.

title: ABL Sensor Mount for Type A Machines Series 1

description.text:
After finally upgrading to the G2 extruder (from the old B3 Pico), I was forced to design a new mount for my ABL sensor (capacitive sensor LJC18A3-H-Z/BX) so I could keep using it. This new ABL sensor mount should be pretty universal for Series 1 (2014+) owners. This sensor is capable of detecting the glass/PEI print bed currently installed in my printer. I wired this sensor through the Series 1's PCB's and ribbon cable to keep things as clean as possible.

Sensor I used here on Amazon: http://www.amazon.com/uxcell-1-10mm-Capacitance-Proximity-Sensor/dp/B00542U3M4

6-4-17 Added "mount5.stl" and "mount6.stl" which are both angled a little differently than "TAM_ABL_Mount.stl," so that the sensor will be more level with the platform. I believe mount6 should be the best bet, but it is currently untested. I am still using mount5 with a small plastic shiv in between the mounting hardware to angle it back a bit.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200

Infill:

40%

Notes:

PRINT ORIENTATION: I printed mine standing up (flat surface down on print bed), with a small amount of support material to hold up the overhangs.

I have found that with the current models, sanding the inside of the ring a little bit helps with fitting the sensor properly. I may adjust this on the model in the future, maybe to make it unnecessary to sand.

BASIC HARDWARE INSTALL NOTES:
Disconnect hotend from X-axis PCB.
Remove two lower screws and nylon nuts from X-axis PCB.
Slide mount up into place (over hotend terminal and around PCB) and fasten with two M3x6 screws.
Re-connect hotend to X-axis PCB.
Insert sensor wire through mounting hole from the bottom and carefully "unscrew" the sensor to the desired position (turning it counter-clockwise will pull the sensor up through the hole), and tighten down with provided nuts.
Wiring info may be added later, but can be found elsewhere for now. Should be pretty straight forward though.

DIY MARLIN FIRMWARE MODIFICATION: To make this work I basically just followed Thomas Sanladerer's instructions in one of his Youtube videos, and for now I'll link directly to the firmware section of the video I primarily used while learning how to set this up: https://youtu.be/EcGFLwj0pnA?t=4m35s (I recommend right-clicking on this link and opening the link in a new tab or window, otherwise it will just play the video from the beginning via Thingiverse)

Modified "Series 1 / Series 1 Pro (2015 with Heated Bed - v1.3.0)" Firmware with ABL pre-configured: https://goo.gl/AHRuvD

comments.text:
Good design. The OEM bracket is a horrid piece of garbage that blocks the filament release, so any time you change filament you will wiggle the sensor and get a failed print as a result.
Do you happen to know the thread size on the sensor?
comments.author: OldRick

comments.text: Thanks! Unfortunately I am not exactly sure of the thread size on the sensor I use, or the thread size on TAM's sensor. After seeing photos of TAM's new ABL system, I thought it looked like it was in the way of the filament release... so I am not surprised of the issues you described. Because the ABL sensor that I use with this bracket is totally different from the one that comes with new Series 1s, I can't say this will be compatible with their sensor without additional modifications to this design.
comments.author: OldRick

comments.text: Any chance of getting the source files, so I can remix one to fit their sensor if needed?
comments.author: nonaym

comments.text: Sorry, but for the time being I am not releasing any source files for my designs. This design will need a major re-design to fit TAMs sensor, and thus it would be best to start a new design from scratch. You could always download the STL and trace the parts you want to keep in your CAD software.
comments.author: OldRick

comments.text:
Fair enough, but from your images, the only thing needing redesign is the ID of the hole - their current sensor appears to be skinnier.
I'll edit the STL in TinkerCAD.
comments.author: nonaym

comments.text: In my opinion changing the ID of the hole will leave you with a lot of excess/unnecessary material, which is why I say it would need some re-designing. This is my inner perfectionist talking... I'm also not really sure if their sensor comes with any mounting hardware (like the nuts and locks I have) other than their junky looking 3d printed bracket. I do not think it is ideal to rely on friction alone to hold the sensor in place... best of luck!

title: Teach Angles by Making a Modular Protractor!

description.text: This lesson is designed to help students build a visual understanding of different angle sizes. If students go through the experience of making their own protractor with modular parts than they'll improve their ability to estimate and measure angles. This projects includes a sample modular protractor but the goal is to show students how to make one for themselves.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

These are pretty easy to print. The 180 degree model will require supports depending upon how you print it.
CCSS

Protractors can be tough for students to understand mainly because the markings go in both directions. With this modular protractor you can have students use one angle measure at a time. Then the different angles can be combined to equal bigger angles. This will greatly improve their ability to estimate angles and subsequently improve their ability to measure angles using a protractor. Imagine a student know that the angle they are measuring is 120 degrees and not 60 because they remember that the 120 degree was bigger. Overview and Background
Student will learn how to estimate and measure the size of angles by using a modular protractor and later they'll make their own. Objectives
Students will be able to estimate and measure angles. Standards
Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.MD.C.5
Recognize angles as geometric shapes that are formed wherever two rays share a common endpoint, and understand concepts of angle measurement:
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.MD.C.5.A
An angle is measured with reference to a circle with its center at the common endpoint of the rays, by considering the fraction of the circular arc between the points where the two rays intersect the circle. An angle that turns through 1/360 of a circle is called a "one-degree angle," and can be used to measure angles.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.MD.C.5.B
An angle that turns through n one-degree angles is said to have an angle measure of n degrees.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.MD.C.6
Measure angles in whole-number degrees using a protractor. Sketch angles of specified measure.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.4.MD.C.7
Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.

After you have students use the protractor teach them to make their own. Using Tinkercad.com this can be done easily using the built in protractor. Step 1
Start on a blank work plane and drag over a red square from the shapes toolbar. Step 2
Make the square into a thinner stick Step 3
Select the stick and copy->paste the shape and don't move it. Step 4
Click on the double headed arrow and you can rotate it. the protractor will appear and a student can rotate the shape and reach the desired angle. Make sure to observe the direction in which you teach the students to rotate the stick. Step 5
Drag over a hole square and remove the excess from the two sticks. You should have a shape with the desired angle. Step 6
Now drag over some number from the text toolbar and label the angle. I use an "O" and shrink it to represent the degree symbol. Step 7
Select all the shapes and group them. Make sure all the shapes are touching. Now you can use this process to make several different angles. There are different ways of joining the pieces so I'll leave that up to you. You can use this with many of the already available online worksheets and other resiurces. I've even had my student use this in the computer lab and they just hold up the model to the screen. It works great with code.org courses where they need to measure the degrees of a turn.
2-3 classes

I would start with some review of angle concepts and maybe make a few worksheets to have some pre-assessment information. This website has a variety of worksheets that are common core aligned: http://www.commoncoresheets.com/Angles.php This website is good for a visual understanding of angles: http://www.homeschoolmath.net/teaching/g/measure_angles.php This website is great for exit quizzes: www.thatquiz.org

Step 1 Step 2 Step 3 - Select the stick and copy and paste it. you'll notice the newly pasted shape appears right next to the first one. Step 4 From here you click and drag on the double headed arrow and rotate the stick. The protractor will appear and you'll be able to make an angle of your choosing. Once rotated prepare to eliminate the excess using a hole box Don't forget to select both shapes and group. Either ctrl+A and ctrl+G or use the toolbar buttons Now drag over some numbers and group everything again.

description.text: Tried my hand at creating an electoral college map of the lower 48. At full scale, each state's height is its electoral vote in millimeters.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2064mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed at .2064 to make sure the difference between 3 and 4 vote states was not lost. I only used 1 shell as each state's border is rendered separately. When I printed this on my printerbot, I scaled it to half size. In that case, the boundary between states that have the same number of votes (e.g. North/South Dakota) is faintly visible. There are technically gaps along the state borders, but at that scale they are lost to the print resolution.

Started with this map: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:SVG_maps_of_the_United_States#/media/File:Blank_US_Map_48states.svg

I used Inkscape to clean up some of the details and added a border. From there, I imported it into Fusion 360 where it was quite easy to extrude each state based on its electoral vote count. Nebraska and Maine have a slightly different method of allocating electoral votes, but I just added them together in those cases.

description.text: Students use 3D printed models as a substitute for more expensive and more dangerous parts in auto shop.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I used the recommendations from the original page, where there are assembly drawings and parts lists,
I found this on Thingiverse at the request of the auto shop teacher looking for a way to include a special needs student in his auto shop class.

We have students in an auto class that have difficulty working on actual cars. This model is an excellent tool to have students work on without the danger of breaking anything of great value. This project came out of an actual classroom situation where a student with special needs could not pass the safety test to be allowed in the shop. He was able to work on this model (which is why there is not yet a picture of the completed thing). The entire time he worked on it, he was able to identify the parts, what they did, and how they were all supposed to go together. Objectives To give students a hands-on experience in auto shop that they may not be able to get otherwise. Audience Grades 9-12 Subjects Auto
Science Skills Learned (Standards) Students understand small and compact engines: Understand engine theory for both two- and four-stroke cycle engines.
Know different types of small engines and their applications.
Know small engine parts and explain the various systems (e.g., fuel, ignition,
compression, cooling, lubrication systems).
Know how to troubleshoot and solve problems with small engines.
Know how to disassemble, inspect, adjust, and reassemble a small engine.

This engine can be assembled by the instructor and used for demonstration purposes, or it can be used by the student to assemble as a project.
In our case, we gave the student the parts (color-coded) with the assembly drawing and he sorted the parts according to the drawings. While he was waiting for the special-order screws to arrive, he attached the parts with string (see drawing). He then started to put things together, but ran out of time at the end of the summer and could not finish. I would recommend having all the parts required before assembly begins. This required close supervision by another teacher just to make sure that the directions were followed.
Assembling the engine could take two weeks of class time (our student volunteer was not able to get it finished in that amount of time, so it would vary based on the ability of the student.)

Printing this engine requires a large commitment of time and resources. If this is going to be part of a lesson, it is best to start a semester ahead to get it printed. If more than one engine is required, allot even more time.
After printing, there is a parts list of fasteners and bearings that will also need to purchased. The small metric screws were difficult to obtain, and had to be special ordered.
http://www.clackamascareers.com/media/uploads/LITINCTELessonPlan-Automotive-EngineDesign.pdf

description.text: This is an enhancement of a lesson taught in English and Language Arts classes. Students are asked to create a board game that represents a book that they have read, and will use a 3D printer to create the game pieces for the game that relate to the subject of the book.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

100% infill is not necessary for these parts. Standard settings should suffice.

These pieces representing the Harry Potter series of books were found on Thingiverse. I shrunk them down to game-piece size (1" high 25% scale) as an example of what can be done. Students should design their own game pieces representing an assigned book.
CCSS

There are many lessons out there for having students create board games as a formative assessment of their knowledge of a subject - in this case a book they have read. They have to understand the book in order to incorporate themes into their games. This lesson plan just adds the 3D design element of creating the game pieces using design software and a 3D printer. Objectives
Students will create a game that reinforces knowledge of the content of a book using 3D printing to create the game pieces. Skills Learned
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.9-10.1
Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.9-10.2
Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.9-10.3
Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.
CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RL.9-10.6
Analyze a particular point of view or cultural experience reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States, drawing on a wide reading of world literature. Duration
This could be an end-of-semester project that students could work on outside the school environment, but would need at least 2 class periods to design their game pieces to be printed.

Each student group would be assigned a book to gamify. They would then work in their group to develop a strategy for the game, questions to ask while playing that show knowledge of the subject (at least 25), and a design for the game pieces that would need to be created.

• Student groups would need to be assigned a book.
  • Student groups need access to a computer with design software.
  • 3D printer with filament.
    • For the gameboard:
  • Poster board for the game board (Or file folders on a smaller scale)
  • Blank index cards for the game questions
  • Spinner or dice
At least two class periods

(taken from http://www.readwritethink.org/files/resources/lesson-docs/NovelBoardGameRubric.pdf) 1.Make your game board neat, colorful, interesting, and creative! 2.Create at least 25 questions and answers for your game that relate to the novel. The questions must be somehow incorporated into playing the game. 3.Relate the format and purpose of your game to the novel in some way. Example: the game board is in the shape of a castle or the purpose is to escape the evil grandmother. 4.Write directions for your game that would make it perfectly clear how to play the game. Type the directions include them with the game 5.Make sure the content and difficulty of your game are appropriate for your novel and for your classmates’ abilities
http://www.readwritethink.org/files/resources/lesson-docs/NovelBoardGameRubric.pdf

remixed_from.title: Coin Slot Lid for Canning Jar

title: Screw Jar Lid for Pint or Half Pint Wide Mouth Ball or Mason Jar

description.text:
I'm working on some non canning designs which require that a screw lid which mates with a standard mason or ball jar.  I printed a number of the existing thingiverse designs before deciding that I needed my own accurate base model for my subsequent designs. I'm putting this base model up because it's useful, as is, in it's own right.  
NOTE: ADDED Original Solidworks 2014 design file as well as STEP and Parasolid.

The glass part of a wide mouth Mason or Ball canning jar has a 0.25 inch pitch single turn thread with a base diameter of approx 2.63 inches. A minimum side wall thickess of about .060 was chosen to insure a robust abaility to torque it down. It could be thinner. Looking at the photos you'll see that there is a flat ring on the inside of the top. This matches the rim of the jar and provides an improved landing/seal zone for the lid.
This particular jar lid was designed from scratch in Solidworks 2013 then printed on an Ordbot Hadron Printer in ABS with a modified QU-BD stepstruder. It was printed using a 1.75 mm ABS filament with a layer thickness of .2 mm (200 microns) and an 85% fill factor with scaffolding support turned off.
ABS Printing was performed at 235C on clear Monokote film over a heated glass bed at 110C for the first layer and 100C for all subsequent layers. Aquanet Extra Super Hold was sprayed on the Monokote to insure stick down. I've had no ABS stick down issues since I began using the above technique.

comments.text: Just as an observation, this seems to be the standard size ball, kerr or mason jar lid, possibly large, but not the Wide. For Wide, multiply x and y by 1.25 and the lid fits Wide mouth jars perfectly. (In my experience.)

description.text: In this lesson, students will find a way to present the solar system to scale using 3D design and printing.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I always use rafts, but they probably were not necessary in this case.
This print was found on Thingiverse.com and is used as an example of how one can display planets to scale. I printed it as it was, then modified the .stl to show the names of the planets.
CCSS

This project was born out of a Summer School theme at my school. Every summer we study space, and I thought it would be great to 3D print a solar system. It was surprisingly difficult to find system already made that would give accurate dimensions. Students will learn about the proportions of the solar system and have to decide how they would like to portray that. The one shown has the smaller planets quite small in order to fit the model. The question to ask would be "how can we stay within the boundaries of the printer, but still create an accurate model?" Objectives Students will learn about the sizes of the planets in our solar system and develop a way to display the planets to scale using 3D design and printing. Audience Grades 9-12 Subjects Science (Earth Science, Physical Science)
Math (proportions)
Art (3D design) Skills Learned (Standards) ESS1: Earth’s Place in the Universe
HS-ESS1-4. Use mathematical or computational representations to predict the motion of orbiting objects in the solar
system
ESS1.B: Earth and the Solar System
Kepler’s laws describe common features of the motions of orbiting objects, including their elliptical paths around the sun. Orbits may change due to the gravitational effects from, or collisions with, other objects in the solar system. (HS-ESS1-4)
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSN.Q.A.2
Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSN.Q.A.3
Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

Students will be introduced to the size of the planets. If possible, the instructor should have visual aids to demonstrate the proportional relationships (basketball vs golf ball vs grain of sand, etc)
Students will then brainstorm ways to display the planets with accurate size (Note that if the sun is included in the model, the rest of the planets will have to be tiny. If the sun is left out of the design, you may be able to get a visible display.
Once the students have formulated a plan, they will use 3D design software (like Tinkercad) to design printable models to create their display.

Student groups will each need a computer with design software.
Students will need a reference sheet with planet sizes listed (attached)

• ESS1
  • HS-ESS1-4
  • ESS1.B
The design of the planets could take up to a week of class time, and printing would be an additional time depending on printer capacity, size of models and speed of the printer.
https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/docs/modelingsolarsystem_20070112.pdf

description.text: What started as an interest to re-purpose an old, unusable wrist watch soon became a pile of broken parts, the insides of many reclaimed time keeping devices, and many hours a-wasted. Eventually, a dial with watch hands was found amok the chaos and things started to look promising. I have worn this watch every day since then for two months and have yet to damage it. This very functional watch casing will fit a 26.5mm crystal and dial, although I'm sure that it could be scaled to fit larger components. To complete the build one will need a 3d Printer, and a complete set of parts from a watch or two that have potential for greatness.

Makerfarm 8

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Try to avoid taking the hands off a watch face if at all possible... Save yourself a lot of headache!

1. Download
  2. Print
  3. Assemble (all the parts should press fit into place but a little dab of hot glue goes a long way)
  4. Be happy and always know the time

These models each represent a multivariable function f(x,y) for which f(0,0) is undefined. However, in each case, one can ask the question of whether or not the limit of f(x,y) as (x,y) approaches (0,0) exists. The three functions from these models are

  1. xy / (x2 + y2)
  2. xy2 / (x2 + y4)
  3. sin(x2 + y2) / (x2 + y2)

It turns out that in the first two examples, the limit does not exist, but in the third one it does.

Since the Oneplus seems to be the only phone on earth with the micro USB port facing the wrong way I made this holder.

I printed it on a hundred years old Stratasys SHDM1000 - "good enough".

With this holder you can actually make use of the Flir One attached to the Oneplus and not just take hot selfies.

This is a cyclone separator for a shop vac. I recommend printing with .3mm layer height and at least 3 shells. Thinner layers are not recommended. The walls on this print are probably quite a bit thicker than they need to be, but the end product is pretty robust. It took a little over 1.5kg of filament and around 24 hours to print on my Lulzbot.

I glued this together using black ABS pipe glue. The same stuff used for drainage pipes. Mine was old and really thick and unusable, but I mixed some acetone in it and mixed it until the abs glue was useable again. I applied it pretty liberally and then wiped away the squeeze out.

I had to do quite a bit of sanding on the bottom edge of the top half to get the pieces to fit together. If I was to make another revision I would probably allow for some clearance between the pieces.

The final finishing step I did was to sand the outside with 100 grit sandpaper knocking down some of the layers then spray the whole thing with Plasti Dip spray finish which is a fairly thick, rubbery finish. This was both for aesthetics and to help seal any potentially tiny gaps between layers. I don't really think this step is necessary considering how thick the walls are.

The base requires 3/8 bolts and washers. I attached it to a standard 5 gallon bucket with a piece of 1/4 MDF as a backer.

Designed using Fusion360. This was designed for and printed on a Lulzbot Taz 5 printer and may not work with smaller 3D printers.

Fusion part: http://a360.co/2mt6TKt

comments.text:
Hello,
I was browsing things and came accross this dust separator.
I'm not sure to understand how that works.
Does the dust stays in the bucket and the rest goes to the vac or is it the opposite ?
comments.author: Kropernic

comments.text: It causes the air entering the cone to spin around like a cyclone.  This causes any particles to be slung against the walls of the separator and fall into the bucket.  Generally the bigger the particle the easier it is to filter out because it has more mass.  Ideally all of the matter ends up in your bucket and not the shopvac.  If you are vacuuming up really small particles like sawdust it will save you a lot of $$ by not clogging up your filters causing them to need frequent replacement.

description.text:
These are two surfaces used in a lesson published by Margaret Reese (citation below). The lesson gives students the formulas for the surfaces of two "mountains":

f(x,y) = 100 - 2x2 - y2

g(x,y) = 100 + 3x2 - 2y2

Students are then asked to use the use the tools of mutlivariable calculus and differential equations to find (for a given starting point):

  1. The steepest possible path up the mountain
  2. A path which ascends the mountain at 50% of the maximum possible steepness.
  3. A path which ascends the mountain at a constant grade of 50%.

When assigning this project, I had students sketch the paths they found on the model.

Project source: Reese, Margaret. Computing Project for Multivariable Calculus. PRIMUS. Vol. 6, Iss. 2, 1996.

description.text:
The hotend mount "Prusa i3 Bowden Extruder + Inductive Proximity Sensor + Radial Fan" is great but has a slot for a 12 mm sensor whereas my sensor has 18mm diameter. Therefore I created this OpenSCAD design which enables you to customize the mount for the proximity sensor. You can change the mounting plate dimensions and the hole diameter any way you like. The default settings produce a mount for 18mm proximity sensor which is also available as an STL file.

Requires "V2_Bowden_e3dv6_radial_fan_proximity_sensor_v2.stl" from the original design. That is where you can also get the other parts like the fan duct and the clamp.

title: Servo driven tracked rover w/suspensions (self tightning belts).

description.text:
3d printed tracked rover from Lynlim Nesneros on Vimeo.

There are ment to be glued on some rubber square`s at the flat side of the tracks You need: Filament Glue Self tapping screws with a wide head M5 screws (do not use any countersink screws on this project) Bearings 16x 5x10x4 MR105ZZ 2x standard size servo w/mod for continus rotation (I used Towerpro 966MG) Start by fasten the front to the middle part, use 2 self tapping screws and glue. Fasten servo with servohorn tap heading forward. Screw in the back parts thrught the hole in part. center and fasten the servohorn to gear, fasten gear to servo. screw on side skirts use 3mm filament, burn the end and stump them flat. do this at both sides, make it tight. Assembly bearings to back part, suspension pins and wheels. Sand suspension pins to fit the chassi, they have to turn pretty free. use grease. secure the back suspesion pin with a wide head screw. Fasten wheels to suspesion pins. Fasten back wheel (all wheels are assembled bearing turning out) Set in the springs, easiest if you set it in the chassi first. Assemble belt, use the filament trick. 33 tracks per belt. you can change belt tension by changing wheels to smaller or bigger ones. (depence on what springs you have) assembly the last track when belt is stretched on place, and last chain over the gear, makes it easier Ready to connect to RC, arduino or what ever you like :)

Signs for miniature railways. Make your own in the customizer. If you don't want holes in the corners, putting zero in the hole size box will fill them in.
Putting a small number in the countersink box will produce a countersink on all four corner holes.
F space is the letter spacing. 1.1 works well for printing.
Using some different fonts may produce odd vertical line spacing. To tweak this, you need to alter the translate statements in the customiser. If there is too much problem, I will try and put some extra variables in!

This is the next stage from thing:1276179
The single line version can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1737675

For those that don't know, the fonts used by customizer include Google fonts https://fonts.google.com/ Typing one of these in will alter your typeface.

Update - I made a mistake in the code that only shows up with a large letter depth. Code now fixed!

description.text:
I designed the silver/white sword from the NES Legend of Zelda game a few different ways. description.text:
This is a customizable Living Hinge, which I think was invented by http://www.thingiverse.com/SNIJLAB/about. The Customizer is designed to give people a feel for what my program can do. The idea for this is to simply add a living hinge in OpenSCAD with a function, and output a DXF that can be sent to a laser cutter.

The following parameters are customizable:
length = the y dimension of the hinge, parallel to the laser cuts
width = the x dimension of the hinge, transverse to laser cuts
d=the distance between parallel laser cuts
What is the minimum distance that two parallel lines can be apart before the laser does something catastrophic? E.g. setting uncontrollable fire to the work piece. This is "minimum_thinness"
hinge_length=the distance between 2 colinear laser cuts
hinges_across_length=the number of hinges across the length of the hinge
"center" is a boolean value, if true, place the center of the rectangle at the origin, if false, put the bottom left corner at the origin (just like square() and cube())

If you want to understand how they work:
http://www.deferredprocrastination.co.uk/blog/2011/laser-cut-lattice-living-hinges/

If you want to see the inventor's website:
https://www.snijlab.nl/en

Please leave any feature requests (OR BUGS!) in the comments. My hope is to add this as an OpenSCAD library.

See this thing's development in almost real time: http://forum.openscad.org/Living-Hinges-td18217.html#a18303

EDIT (26 AUG 2015): Added "add_hinge()" functionality, so now you can simply write add_hinge() circle(), to put a hinge in a circle. Thank you, Ronaldo Persiano.

Notes:

This is not intended to be printed with a FFF printer, but instead cut with a laser engraver.

title: T42 to Canon EF-S lens Adapter (Work in progress)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
T42 AKA M42, 42mm to Canon EF-S.

This adapter will enable you to use most any manual lens with a EF-S mount on any camera or adapter that accepts a 42mm thread. The flange/sensor distance needs to be considered when adapting a lens to your camera. My use case is to adapt a cheap camera bellows thats only available with a EF-S mount to be used as the focusing mechanism for fixed focus enlarger lenses.

The adapter prints in 2 pieces, the 42mm threaded side can be extended to change the sensor to lens distance to accommodate various camera models.

Check out v2 as i have completely redesigned the adapter to have a shorter flange distance. The necessary supports are built into the the bottom half. Do not enable supports. v2 has been printed and is a perfect fit.

Printer:

HicTop Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:

Orientate with the 42mm thread side down. The EF-S mounting side has built in supports that need to be removed.

Printed in ProtoPasta Carbon Fiber PLA, very little finish work has to be done as it has a nice mat finish. The part is very strong and rigid with the CF-PLA but ABS or PET-G would be fine. Straight PLA is to soft at such thin diameters.
Drawn in tinkercad, if requested i will add a tinkercad link so the part can be edited.

Close model of the one George Matheis (Modern Combatives System) designed for Alpha Innovations, only I optimized it a bit for 3D printing namely a tad thicker webs and a better palm swell for those with less meaty hands.

FWIW plastic knuckles are LEGAL in Canada (where I reside) as per this CBSA document (it is YOUR responsibility to confirm legality in your country of residence, I cannot be held responsible):

http://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/publications/dm-md/d19/d19-13-2-eng.html#a4x2

 

(46). Brass knuckles can be combined with other weapons such as knives. These ‘brass knuckles knives' consist of two parts: a knife blade, and brass knuckles integrated into the handle. The blade part does not generally possess characteristics that would make it fall under the definition of prohibited weapon. Rather, it is the brass knuckles handle that will usually determine the knife's classification as a prohibited weapon. In order for the knife to be prohibited, the brass knuckles part of the knife must meet the definition of "brass knuckles" in the regulations. Therefore, to classify a ‘brass knuckles knife' as prohibited:
 
(a) the handle must be a weapon; and
(b) that weapon must meet the definition of brass knuckles. It is not sufficient for the blade portion of the knife to be designed as a weapon.
 
Exception: The following goods generally do not meet the definition of prohibited weapon, and thus do not fall under tariff item 9898.00.00. Their misuse may nonetheless be punishable under other laws:
 
(a) plastic knuckles do not fall within the definition of "brass knuckle";
(b) D-guard knives (knives with a hand-guard in the form of a "D").

 
FOR EDUCATIONAL/NOVELTY PURPOSES ONLY, VIRTUAL RENDERING/PROOF OF CONCEPT

See proper knuckle usage here (coincidentally taught by the designer):

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1QKHQuGcJ0U
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=njW0gIrp-wE
http://www.moderncombativesystemsblog.com/2016/08/knuckles-101-part-i-selection-carry.html

Post Processing Finishing

1)Sand down with a grit of 120 to 400

3)Lightly sand down rough parts with 400 grit sand paper so flaws are still visible
4)Prime for painting

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr. 1.0

If you, like me, wear glasses, then you know how frustrating it is to have dirt on your glasses. Fingerprints, spots, that kind of things that spoil your view.

Now some shops sell those Optical Lens Wipes that have moisture in them and that are great for cleaning your glasses from grease and dirt, but these wipes come in big boxes and you never carry them around.

Therefore I made the Optical Lens Wipe Carry Box, that you can carry on your belt.

It can hold up to 5 sachets of those optical lens wipes so now you never leave your home without them. Clean your glasses everywhere you are and see everything you always wanted to see, without dirt.

Print like I did, without support or use support only from the build plate up (like this is possible to configure in Simplify3D) and have yourself a handy nifty lens cleaner box.

Here is my video on this thing:
https://youtu.be/WT2NTfGYpLg

P.S.: Make it pink, like I did to stand out...

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0 Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

title: Apple Watch + iPhone Stand + AirPods Charger with Watchband Storage

description.text:
This is a combo iPhone charger + AirPods charger + Apple Watch charger + Watchband Storage I created.
It is designed to use Apple's original cables (lightning and watch), but to make them look seamlessly integrated with the dock.

The lightning cable is inserted first (from the bottom) and held in place by a clip. There are three different lightning cable clip sizes to accommodate both naked iPhones and those in cases.

The watch charging cable is inserted next.

Both cables are routed to the back and help in place by a twist&lock base.

Enjoy!

UPDATE: Here's a link to a new wireless model I created for the iPhone X and iPhone 8: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2747867

This is a spatial Bricard 6-Bar linkage that can be made from card stock, best sliced by a laser cutter like the Epilog Zing. ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raoul_Bricard ) There are slogans on the faces. I originally designed this cardboard toy to advertise the Make Lab at our school arts festival called ArtRageous. I called it a mechanical donut, but my more artistic colleagues called it "Perpetual Motion" Feel free to put in your own slogans! Albertus Mus in the Discussion comments also pointed out earlier work related to these folding designs. Check out: (1) IsoAxis ( http://www.ac-noumea.nc/maths/polyhedr/IsoAxis_.htm ) (2) Kaleidocycles ( http://www.kaleidocycles.de/ )

If you do not have a laser cutter, you can also make the toy with plain scissors. Print out on card stock for best results. After you cut out the outline, fold along all the dashed lines, keeping the graphics on the outside. Start assembling by matching up the two edges labeled ^ 1 ^ and taping them together. Continue in sequence with the two edges labeled ^ 2 ^, etc. through ^ 6 ^. You will get a tube like shape with six tetrahedrons attached in alternating positions. Join the first to the last one, to get a closed donut, and tape together the matching edges labeled ^ 7 ^. The linkage is almost ready. Flip the linkage through and tape the two edges labeled ^ 8 ^ together on the other side. The toy is now ready to keep fingers busy!
If cut by laser, the folding is a lot easier. The more accurately you make it, the better it moves.
The .cdr file (Corel Draw format) can print to an Epilog Zing Laser. If you do not have Corel Draw, you can print the .pdf file.

comments.text: Dear Albertus,
comments.author: Guest

description.text:
Ever wondered what that box of desktop components in your closet was planning?  Self-aware componentry can be fairly dangerous especially if your not exactly sure what your looking for.  When scanning your various parts for potential malicious conscientiousness I can provide at least one known variant, the Semi-Volatile Memory or "SVM".
I have encountered multiple SVM's recently and worked out a mutual agreement with the group allowing them full desk surface egress at work and home in return they will not induce hard stop errors or memory buffer overflows on my work and home PC/MAC's.  I pretty much had to take the deal...

1.) Print "HeadAndFoot.stl" for the 8GB RAM stick and SD card
2.) Print "BodyAndArms.stl" for the 8GB FOB drive, USB cables and A type connectors
3.) Clean if needed with an X-ACTO knife
4.) Fit head to body
5.) Fit body to foot
6.) Fit hands to arms
7.) Fit arms into desired arm hole on body depending on preferred angle Place SVM on your desktop and yield to his never-ending semi-volatile memory assault! Pictured SVM's printed on: TOM # 4890
MK6+
1.75mm
.4 nozzle
ABP with aluminum plate topper and titanium belt covered in kapton I have also attached my Sketchup master "SVM.skp" for your modding pleasures. PSA (Public Service Announcement): Always exercise caution when working around unknown components!

title: Kinetic Finger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In May 2015, I set out on a challenge to develop a functional finger prosthetic that would not only be revolutionary, but would be accessible to anybody on the planet- for free.

The "Kinetic finger" is a body-powered device that has no complicated moving parts, and utilizes TPE flexible hinges to allow the finger to open and close in a realistic manner.

The design is unobtrusive, allowing the "Kinetic finger" to be used under work gloves.

During trial, finger amputees were able to pick and place a wide variety of heavy and light objects, as well as play a piano and finger pick a guitar.

The "Kinetic finger" is designed to look like an accessory, similar to a watch, that can be attached and removed as the user pleases.

This is a continuous work in progress, so files will be updated over time. Please share your experiences and trials to help me to continuously improve this design.

Feel free to e-mail me at [email protected] for any questions or feedback.

Please see the videos attached for a demonstration of the "Kinetic finger".

This design is for evaluation purposes only. I will take no responsibility for any accidents or claims as a result of making/ distribution of this design. Thank you.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

(1) PLA Parts: 40% infill, one perimeter, 0.2mm layer height, no supports, no raft, 60mm/sec at 215C.
Proximal phalanx, middle phalanx, distal phalanx, tensioner clip (4 parts)

(2) Ninjaflex (flexible and elastic TPE) Parts: 100% infill, one perimeter, 0.2mm layer height, supports, no raft, 30mm/sec at 230C.
Distal inter-phalangeal hinge, proximal inter-phalangeal hinge, tendon guide (3 parts)

(3) Ninjaflex (flexible and elastic TPE) Parts: 30~50% infill, one perimeter, 0.2mm layer height, no supports, no raft, 30mm/sec at 230C. (to allow for tactile grips)
Distal phalanx grip, middle phalanx grip (2 parts)

All parts should be scaled except for the tendon guide and tensioner clip.
Recommended tendon: 50lb (25kg) braided fishing line.
Recommended Velcro for tensioner clip: double sided 25mm width, 400mm length.
Recommended adhesive: Superglue for tendon and holding grips in place.

Scaling and assembly instructions to come soon.
Index finger test case: 100% scale
Ring finger test case: 90% scale

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/uowrWxK5QsM" ></iframe>
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/hzXtqlpLvbM" ></iframe>

I would like to share with you the key merits of the design in the hope that some of you may find it useful for improving your own designs.
1) Hinges. The flexible hinges have been designed in a "U" shaped configuration to prevent them from flopping around the center point and give improved spring-back. The center is also cut out to prevent the hinge from sliding out during operation. They are fitted from one side, and then stretched to fit from the other side. The hinges have a dampener which forms a part of the knuckle. There are two reasons for this.. The first reason is to allow for silent operation with no contact of plastic parts. The second reason is to fill the gap when opened to allow gloves to be worn without getting caught in the void.
2) Joints: Having the center available in the joint allows the tendon hole to come as far forward and as close to the hinge as possible, requiring less retraction of the tendon to close the finger. Bringing the tendon guide hole as far forward as possible also allows the cavity for the finger to come very close to the joint allowing for realistic finger length when the finger is severed close to the joint.
3) Tendon guide: The flexible tendon guide is comfortable and flexes with the hand. It does not bear the load of the tendon, rather it is only a guide to the rigid tensioner clip. The rigid tensioner clip takes the full load of the tendon, and is fixed to the wrist by a Velcro strap. Therefore, there is no stretching of the flexible tendon guide which improves grip strength.
4) Grips: The grips are also printed in flexible material and provide more grip than plastic. I have also made a scalable mold for super grippy silicone tips which will be uploaded shortly. The grips have key-ways to assist in adhesion when glued into place.

comments.text: I seem to be having trouble getting the fishing line through the last part of the finger (socket) do you have any tips for this?
comments.author: Mikey_i

comments.text:
The "S" bend in the finger is quite aggressive, so normal fishing line might find it difficult to feed initially. I use a braided fishing line that is able to curve around the "S", but it might be more difficult with a more rigid nylon line. If you dont have any braided line, perhaps you could try using a thin piece of cotton to feed through. This will confirm whether it has printed correctly and be able to feed the line. If the cotton comes through, then perhaps you could attach it to the fishing line and pull it back through? Let me know how you go with the cotton.
I am currently working on version 2 which will have a larger diameter hole. In this version it has been kept as small as possible to allow it to be as streamlined as possible to allow the user to wear latex gloves. Let me know how you go. Mat

comments.author: Rach90

comments.text:
The tip of the finger, or the distal phalanx, only has limited movement. It is the middle segment, or the middle phalanx, is the segment that has most movement. So, I am not sure if there would be a huge benefit in doing so. But, I will consider how it can be done for you. Perhaps email me a photo and the dimensions of the finger ( lengths and circumferences of the affected fingers of both hands) and I will see what I can do for you.
Regards,

description.text:
adaption of my original design for the full smart graphics LCD ramps housing. (a couple of people messaged me asking whether there was a small lcd version)

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1639786

This design is specifically for use with the small 4-line lcd display which allows for a more compact case housing and fitment.

both case parts are uploaded in their full length format which measures 185mm in length(the exact size of the printrite control panel mounting panel) but might prove a little difficult to print on the printrite standard 200x200 printbed,, the parts can be easily chopped in half with any 3d program and physically bonded together again with any half decent superglue or abs 3d pen.

to maintain the compact shape Ive positioned one 40mm intake fan mounting point on the left-handside of the base part while a additional 40mm fan can be mounted on the right to assist with exhausting heat from the housing. (both fans can be mounted internally as there is sufficient space inside even after the Arduino and Ramps board are fully installed)

This is a piece to hold the door of my dishwasher slightly opened, to allow for water vapour to exit, after the wash cycle. It holds onto the original locking of the door by sliding it to the pin, and its own pin connects to the body of dishwasher.

As an option, I have added to Customizer, so you can change some settings, like height and length, and fit it to your needs.
